38449015.review:
You are Hamit Kamplar, the most successful door-to-door salesman in northwest Iowa. 

While presenting "The Lawnmower Opportunity" at the annual Tri-State Sales Convention, you see a familiar figure rise from his seat. 

"I have a question," says the man.

"Well, I'm going to have Q&A at the end, but sure if it's quick, Dinthel."

"Thank you. And yes, I am Dinthel Chanberg, everyone. My question is: would you like to buy these tennis shoes?"

"Uh, haha? I don't underst-"

"It is difficult to run in wingtips," Dinthel explains, gesturing at your feet. He takes a deep breath and raises his hands up. "Demon Circle Blaze!"

Light shoots out from the ground with a high-pitched hum. From the stage, you can see a ring completely surrounds yourself and the audience.

A woman shrieks and you look in that direction. She's standing on the ring. Her head expands, engulfing her torso and arms. The ring begins to rotate and sink into the ground. You can see her body still trembling and morphing as she falls out of sight.

"Customer number 1!" Dinthel shouts. "Demon Circle Blaze!"

Another ring appears and all those within it suffer the same fate.

The horror continues until there are just three people left.

"Phew," Dinthel says, wiping his brow with a silk handkerchief. "Now on to business. Hamit. Hello? Yes, you, Hamit. Look here. Would you like to buy these tennis shoes?"

You had stood silently, mouth agape until now. You shake your head. "Wh- why, what, wh--"

"Yes," Dinthel interrupts. "I understand you have many questions, Hamit. But what I want to know is if you would like to buy these tennis shoes. They look to be your size."

You don't know what Dinthel is after, but you feel it would be unwise to refuse his offer outright. "S- sure..."

"Fantastic," Dinthel says, tossing them toward you. "Then we have a deal. Don't wait, put them on. How are they?"

You change into the shoes and walk around a bit. "They fit. They feel great," you report. You're not lying. They truly are the best shoes you've ever worn. "Um, so how much are they?"

Dinthel smiles. "Your soul."

You fall and everything goes black.

-----------------------------------------------------

[h1] Pros [/h1]
+ Hard, but not overly frustrating
You will die a lot. But the penalty for dying is low; you're simply knocked back to the previous circle.
Also, stages have a few "save points". These are circles where you cannot die and thus cannot get knocked back further.

+ Varied gameplay
The game stays (mostly) fresh with several kinds of enemies and mechanics.

+ Great narrative and characters
I really liked Dinthel.

+ Circle Affinity: an additional, endless mode where you go as many circles deep as you can on one life.
The game provides a few different stages with goals for how deep to get.


[h1] Cons [/h1]
- The menu UI is unclear. The first time I played, I started playing the Circle Affinity mode instead of the original game.

- A little bit too long and repetitive.
Despite the good variance, the game does still drag, especially in the last worlds. If you edited out  maybe 15%, the overall game would have been better.

- No voice acting! 

- Ending is a bit abstract. I had come to really care for the characters and wanted more closure.

37583780.review:
I could best describe it as a really challenging puzzle platformer. Every level starts you on the outside of a circle where you must enter a "door" so you can get on the inside layer of the circle before jumping to the next circle, repeating these steps ad finitum until you reach the core. The first step is getting used to the controls (really simple you can only go left or right and jump) and then getting used to never losing your character out of your sight while you are drowned in a barrage of layers. Every level the game keeps introducing new challenges in your way, the circles start moving, new type of enemies and a few diabolical surprises. Trust me you will die a lot, especially if like me you started with the idea of perfecting all the levels (I have now long abandoned such foolish dream)
The game demands all of your attention at all times. Each time you make a mistake, you are set back a circle without much of a pause, so if you fail to remain calm you may start chaining mistakes and get sent way way back. You better clean those tears cause there is only one way to the end, it's persevering.
Once you manage to reach the third world, oh boy, the game not only will require all of your dexterity and concentration, it will find your determination still lacking and will now demand you grow a third eye if you wish to be worthy of his challenge !
Still sweating, once you surpass the third world, maybe you'll go back to the first few levels to get some achievements and you'll wonder how could you ever have thought theses introductory levels to be hard in the past !

It's one the hardest game i've played in my life, one of the few that made me give up numerous times. (I still need to finish world 4 and I don't think my mind can cope with the literal nightmare that probably awaits my soul in world 5) But it never felt unfair, you just need to get a grip and never lose hope !
The game looks great and is mesmerizing just to look at (but really try to not get lost in there).
Also they added for free, a stressful (but really fun !) infinite mode cleverly named Circle Affinity, that I keep coming back to.
And let's not forget the beautiful but haunting soundtrack that completes this singular package.

Storywise i'm pretty sure the game is about depression, but for me Circa Inifnity is a dazzling descent into the hearth of madness.

37511647.review:
This game is split in two parts:

 - challenges that are equal parts puzzle and dexterity
 - an infinite mode in which the puzzle aspect is less present and the focus lies on dexterity and reaction time

Both modes are well fleshed out and very enjoyable. Both modes also have a lot of replayability: the infinite mode for obvious reasons, but the challenges as well, in trying to improve completion time.
    The graphics and soundtrack of this game are very energetic. 
    The gameplay is fresh, interesting and, though simple in concept, very difficult. If it suffers, it is because there is too much going on at once sometimes.

37294654.review:
At first glance Circa Infinity apears an overly simple, quirky, genreless, indy game. Within the first couple levels it becomes so... so much more. Simply eloquent this game is a non-traditional hand-eye platformer of godlen era proportions that is not just mentally demanding but an erudite work of art remeniscent of a bygone era of inovation and injenuity. 

Such simple gimmicks, it is amazing that this has not been done before outside of old school atari paddles; and with such cleverly designed levels requiring more problem solving than hardcore platforming (of which it requires in spades as well) coupled with an exilerating sound track it is surprising more folks have not jumped onto this game. At the writing of this review less than 8,000 people own this game, and in all honesty I hope above all else this becomes a sleeper game of cult propoertions. It most definitely transcends and expands genres that are sorely under developed and deserves a lot more exposure than it has gotten until now.

This game is laudable on so many levels, and I for one cannot recomend it highly enough

In full disclosure, I wrote this review hastilly for the Steam nominations Badge, but i have every intention of coming back and editing this to be an actually useful review giving this game more of the time it deserves.

Also of note it is on sale on steam at the moment, and an extra sale on the humble site

Circa Infinity will trick you, kick you while you're down, and laugh.

It's too complicated for its own good.  It's anger-inducing.  It'll make you wallow in frustration as you're forced upon mistakes to replay difficult levels you just solved - levels you might just also mess up and further set yourself back.

Yet, its intensely sensual art and unique premise make it all worth another go.  From an artistic standpoint, Circa Infinity is simply phenomenal.  It's not afraid to surprise and take risks.  It has something to say, and its briliance will make your jaw drop to the floor.

In all ways, Circa Infinity intends to be brain-melting.  It does exactly that.

35367859.review:
I haven't finished this game yet since I'm busy with school, work, and other games. However, it's a steal. Generally speaking the meta for most Indie games I've seen is all about [genre] remix, remix, remix. There's absolutely nothing wrong with that, but this is why Circa Infinity really stands out. While definitely a platformer, it has this effect of feeling like you've gone from playing in Cartesian Coordinates to Polar Coordinates. The delight in this is that your skills from years of platformers will translate, but you will find yourself utilizing them in unique ways. 

You may experience these types of feelings: where/when you'd normally be focused on positioning, you'll have to focus on timing; when/where you'd emphasize timing, you actually had to emphasize positioning. Etc. The classic feeling of breezing to grappling to breezing to grappling is here as always but again, the cirular/sinusoidal nature of the game gives a new spin on this.

Circa Infinity contains "Postmodern" themes in a form more pure than other games and the soundtrack is quite pleasent. If you enjoy novelty, this is a solid pick. Cheers

34207432.review:
If you liked Super Hexagon, you won't necessarily like this. Super Hexagon's rotation controls were fine because the game was simple and once you got the hang of them you could reach any level of mastery if you pushed yourself far enough. This game is different because you don't just have to focus on the confusing controls, but also the enemies that are pressuring you to act AND in later levels the wedges also start moving around making it very difficult to focus on everything at the same time. I'm not even halfway through the game and it's becoming increasingly frustrating, it's not a game you can play casually (after the second world). It takes dedication just to complete a level, and hours on top of that to finish it in time to get all the achievements.

The achievements all feel contrived, they're all formulaic and mundane (finish world X in Y time and repeat for all worlds) not rewarding or intuitive at all.

The game does have it's good points, the controls are fluid, and the sound effects and music are especially suited to a game like this. Everything feels, looks, and sounds snappy, but that's all undermined by the fake difficulty. I can't even imagine how nightmarish the end-game levels are. It would be okay if they ramped up the difficulty slowly but instead they introduce a new mechanic and then combine them with previous mechanics which makes the game too hard too fast. It's a nice little game, but I have basically zero incentive to finish it, and I completed Super Meat Boy 100% so I know what makes a good challenge.

33318005.review:
I'm all for minimalist games that can just take one idea and run with it.  In Circa Infinity you venture through layers of circles each offering incremental challenges.  Simply run, jump, and dodge your way through each new challenge as you quickly progress deeper and deeper.  This is very much an arcade style game focusing mostly on high-scores and survival.  As the difficulty ramps up it becomes quite a thrilling experience forcing you to make split second decisions.  Speaking honestly Circa Infinity isn't setting out to reinvent the wheel but it is does manage to spin a new yarn.  Alright, gibberish idioms aside I'll try to make sense of this game.

The gameplay sits at the very core of this experience.  You sometimes play as a man, women, or both running around these large circles.  Starting outside the circles you have to get in through a gate at which point you then proceed to run around the inside.  Inside is a floating ball that will take you to the outside of the next circle pushing the last circle out to towards the corners of your screen.  Its makes a lot more sense once you see it but for now just imagine Alice falling down the rabbit hole.  Of course this wouldn't be much of a game without obstacles in your path, at which point monsters come into the picture.

There are a number of beasts trying to block you from completing your objective.  Actually many of them aren't trying to hard as they just sit around crying or hover without moving.  It will be up to you to jump or roll as necessary to progress.  Eventually you'll encounter more menacing threats such as creatures that chase you around or block our path entirely.  Although colliding with a monster only bumps you back one zone this game is so fast-paced that it is easy chain one mistake after another and end up a handful of zones back.  However, once you feel comfortable with a level and can be fun to go back to either improve your time or try to pass the stage with less deaths.

The minimalist visuals make it much easier to keep track of everything happening on screen at any one time.  You'll only have three or so colors on screen making it easy to distinguish where everything is at any given moment.  This is all super important because it can be very disorienting to keep track of what is your left and right when running around on a round plane.  Thankfully the music is very soothing and will help calm your nerves in what can be quite an intense game.  The sound-effects also fit very nicely and really have a pleasant pop to them.

How much you'll like this game will really depend on the type of gamer you are.  If you want a challenge and you enjoy pushing yourself to perfection then I believe this will be right up your alley.  Even if thats not really your thing there is a lot to admire about this unique concept and its clever art design.  However, this is a really tough game and after about a hour and half I was feeling like I was ready to move on.  I enjoyed the time I spent playing Circa Infinity but I was starting to hit that ceiling of difficulty where the challenge was becoming less fun and more of a chore.  That all being said this is a rather inexpensive game it does need a big host of hours to get your worth out of it.

Very good game. One of the most original I've seen in a while. The controls are very good, feels like you are in complete control the entire time and that any mistake is solely to blame on yourself, which is surprising because sometimes platformers like this where you switch directions while being upsidedown can feel wrong or unresponsive. I am the type of person to refuse to play a game if it is slightly unresponsive or if the controls are not well suited for the game, this game is very responsive and the controls work perfectly for it.

The soundtrack is also very good and fits the mood of the game. The bosses are also very well designed (that I've seen so far, this game was so good I felt the need to review it just to help it out right away), as are the enemies, both mechanic wise and how their design reflects their mechanics in the game. The game lends itself to speed running as well, with achievements for it, if you're into that.

32999245.review:
Circa Infinity's gameplay happens within a bunch of circles. Within each circle, you are faced with a bunch of enemies/obstacles to overcome in order to advance to the next circle. Simple, right? NOPE.
This game gets absolutely challenging as you go (especially if you're gunning for the no deaths achievement). It will constantly introduce increasingly difficult enemies that you have to avoid as you progress, as well as throw sections with different types of enemies. Conquering each section will feel deeply satisfying once you figure it out.
The bosses are rather creative in how you defeat them, and are even more challenging than the rest of the game.
There's also a fun arcade mode where you try to survive an endless gauntlet of enemies, which will give you something to do once you finish the main game.
The game is not without flaws, however. The controls certainly have a learning curve to them, and will make playing more difficult than it already is if you don't get used to it. And sometimes, your jumps won't be enough to get you into the next section of the stage, which can lead to potentially infuriating deaths.
All in all, I think pros outweigh cons here. If you're looking for a real challenge, this game is for you.

28927973.review:
Como assim um jogo de plataforma circular? É mais fácil entender o conceito jogando do que lendo, mas vou tentar. Em cada fase você começa do lado de fora de um círculo e, movendo-se apenas para esquerda ou direita, deve passar para a parte interna desse círculo e depois pular para um outro círculo menor. Assim que você consegue, esse círculo se espande e outro aparece dentro dele, para onde você deve ir. Entre essas "camadas" há vários tipos de capetinhas vermelhos que te matam ao te tocar.

Conforme você vai avançando pela fase, os círculos vão se acumulando nas bordas da tela e você ainda consegue ver todos os capetinhas que estavam nele. O efeito é muito louco, parecido com olhar um caleidoscópio.

Quando você acha que dominou a mecânica do jogo, ele joga novas regras na sua cara, te obrigando a controlar dois personagens ao mesmo tempo, que ainda por cima ficam em lados opostos da tela! Seus olhos ficam iguais ao de um camaleão e te dá a forte sensação de que é preciso mais de um cérebro para jogar bem [i]Circa Infinity[/i].

Sério, esse jogo exige tanta coordenação visual e motora que podia ser aplicado nas provas do Detran. Não sei se terei capacidade de zerar, mas recomendo a experiência.

[h1] 本篇致力于写一篇不一样的评测，因为这款游戏的内涵不容埋没。	[/h1]

我是上个月才看到这游戏，看了几张截图，就明白这游戏注定意味着什么，赶紧付了全款，并在接下来的半个月时间，每天与自己的一个佛教信徒朋友定时探讨。直到这个月我终于通了关，整理清楚半个多月来的心得笔记，就来到了这里。
先就游戏性体验说上几句：

+游戏难度：如果有玩家在手机端玩过这游戏，会发现电脑版真是良心……在手机上我最多打到3.9关。手机版的游戏速度比电脑版快太多，更要命的是按钮设置太别扭，这两点任何一点都很致命。而电脑版从开始到最终关，游戏速度都很平衡，只要不是太心急，都能过关。（至于眼晕不晕的问题，在后面的部分我会详细说明）
-游戏手感：对手柄摇杆的支持很作死，如果你用摇杆你会死的最快……所以只能用手柄的左、右键来控制人物移动了，从这点上来说，跟手机版也没啥区别了啊……
-游戏BMG：这是最令我疑惑的一点。我在手机端玩的时候，每关都有好听的音乐。而在STEAM上，我只能听到人物音效，但是绝对听不到背景音乐！我从头打到尾，没有任何一关让我听到背景音乐！不论我怎么找设置选项，事实上原声OST我也有买了，但是我就是在游戏中没有听到任何一首音乐！不知道别的玩家是不是也是这样？
-游戏成就：罢了，这辈子是不用指望全成就了…………相信开挂变速齿轮减8倍速外加强迫症严重者一定能够达到。至于我嘛，我就在角落里蹲十分钟泪目一会儿就算了。

25703947.review:
This game does everything that a platformer puzzle game should. It takes a unique concept, and milks it for every ounce of gameplay potential it's worth. It is fast paced but filled with a good mix of tricky puzzles and tricky timing/platforming. It does a very good job of constantly adding (very creative) twists onto the central concept and ramping up the complexity until the last few levels are exceedingly complicated.

As for length, it's longer than I expected it to be. There's five chapters of equal length and I fully expected it to be out of ideas and end after chapter 4, and it would have still felt like a complete game by the end of chapter 3. And many of the acheivements could be considered to be additional bonus puzzles in themselves (ie "find a level in this chapter that's possible only running in one direction"), giving it a bit of extra replayability.

Overall, good game. Would recommend to anyone who likes creative puzzles and unique concepts.

25024960.review:
Circa Infinity is a very unique puzzle platformer. Usual platforms are straight, or at most some kind of slope. Here it's concentric circles and it's insane.

You enter a new circle from the bottom. You go to the right. You enter the next circle from the top. You go to the right... No. Your character is going left. Right and left are actually counter-clockwise and clockwise, which creates confusion over and over again when the brain is still used to consider that the button to the right should always move the character in that direction. Also, jump is actually some sort of slide when the character is not yet in the inner circle... Reacting the right way on short notice is really difficult. Difficult but fun, with the cool music and visuals. The first two worlds are a treat.

However, the next worlds lost me. Two characters are controlled at the same time, and it's just too hard to follow (suddenly much more a puzzle than a platformer) while not flowing as well as when it was only one character. It's like constantly being tethered to something fragile and annoying.

But before it came to that point, I really had a good time, and found the level design excellent (there are both series of levels, and an infinite mode). The game teaches you what each enemy does before spicing things up or mixing with other enemies, and it makes sure that you understood by placing them in a smart way several times and making you go back one circle upon death. Some circles are devoid of obstacles and can't kill you, they effectively act as subtle checkpoints or safe havens that prevents you from being ousted back to the beginning of that inferno.

In conclusion, despite some elements that put me off, it's a good few hours fun for anyone into unique or hardcore platformers.

24401479.review:
Circa Infinity是一个集瞎眼、烧脑、残手于一体的游戏。
游戏操作方式正如游戏名称所说的一样简单直白：转圈，躲避怪物，一圈一圈地进入深层到达终点。
和与之操作方式相类似的Super Hexagon相比，游戏性明显比强了不少，大概是因为拥有了Boss关卡的概念，而且也不会像Super Hexagon玩到后面高难度时“Begin”语音满天飞。
Circa Infinity还有一个Speedrun模式，看看你完成整个5章（55关）需要多少时间，对于竞速玩家来说这是个不错的挑战。

========= 分割线 =========
本以为Circa Infinity就这样就没了，后来某次更新竟然还出了一个Circa Affinity游戏模式，惊喜。
原以为主游戏模式足够瞎眼烧脑残手的了，结果看来是我图样图森破，Circa Affinity游戏模式简直更暴力地上了N层楼，更加完美的呈现了什么叫做瞎眼（附带惊悚音效）。
我就不描述了，得自己亲身体验，我去做眼保健操去了。

========= 总评 =========
操作：10/10，操作简单，四个方向键就行
设计：10/10，主菜单这种设计我很喜欢
画面：10/10，瞎眼无极限，主模式通关动画简直好看
音效：10/10，我就是冲着Soundtrack买的这游戏

这大约是我玩过最好的一个残手游戏了！

24151594.review:
Immaculate.

In nearly every aspect, Circa Infinity has vastly exceeded my expectations, and sits well near the top of my list of most intelligently designed games I have ever played. A minimalist, puzzle platformer is the last game I would expect to enjoy this immensely amongst a sea of indie titles. I consider the genre to be the equivalent of the FPS of the indie scene: a sort of formulaic attempt to tread ground into the industry, but CI is perhaps the most exhilarating take on a tired template in every aspect of its design. It will consistently challenge your thinking while simultaneously presenting you every tool necessary to complete and appreciate the pieces which meld this wonderful game.

At its core, CI is commonly described as a circular platformer. In a step far to the left, the game involves no vast worlds, but simply a monochrome series of circles laden with enemies. It begins simply: have your character enter each circle, avoid every monster, and jump inwards to the next circle until you complete the level. Each level is comprised of around 10 circles or so, with every few levels introducing a new mechanic. It remains fairly simplistic through the first of five worlds, bringing in new enemies and covering most of what you'll need to complete the remainder. 

Circa Infinity respects your intelligence. If you fail and touch an enemy, the only punishment you receive is that you must return to the previous circle. Rather than simply start the current challenge over, you must re-surmount the former, meaning that consistent missteps can place you back at the start of the level. There are checkpoints in each level every few circles, however, so even as it gets crazier, there are plenty of chains of challenges which are short and allow you to focus on them, as they become quite complex. New worlds bring in major mechanics additions, with the brilliant tutorialisation that never leaves the player confused. I won't go into them, as divulging every mechanic feels akin to spoiling a major plot. Part of CI's joy is discovering how each new world builds off of the rules that you know, and they remain clear, concise, and straightforward. That said, Circa Infinity will force you to think in manners that toss everything you know about games on its head. 

Speaking of plot, the game is entirely devoid of dialogue or narration, and every piece of the story is told through imagery. This is a bold step from the game's early builds, wherein the breakpoints between levels were filled with text explaining the adventure you undertake. I feel the game works far better without it, retaining its minimalist feel and remaining atmospheric in a way that words would only detract from. 

And nothing lends itself more to the game's atmosphere than the music. God, the music. Easily one of the best game soundtracks I have ever heard, with even the tracks playing between levels reaching unexpected levels of intricacy and power. In a game that feels a lot about going from level to level and jumping between speeding through and thinking out the next series of moves, in only this instance would I recommend taking a break to sit and breathe, as your characters do, and take a listen between stages. The break music from the first world, a track I would normally skip, surprised me as becoming one of my favorite songs in the entire game when I took the time to sit instead of plowing ahead. The music is more than enough of a reward for finishing some of these heinous treks. 

If that package weren't enough, Kenny Sun recently added the game mode: Circle Affinity, which adds a randomized, endless, high-score style romp reminiscent of Super Hexagon. It's not nearly as difficult, but is always fun, and one of the few “get as far as you can” game modes I enjoy. Especially in an age where the sort of play-til-you-drop gameplay has fallen out of favor, CA adds a nice alternative to the pre-designed levels and usual speedrunning romps. Mr. Sun is quite generous in providing for free a game mode which could have easily stood alone for a few bucks. The additions to the soundtrack never hurt either, with some remixes and a few new favorites; I anxiously await its additional release.

Of course, no game is perfect. Circa Infinity is a touch short (which is of course, remedied by CA), and finishing the game felt a tad bittersweet. 
Getting used to knowing which direction you're going in can take some time and will throw you off occasionally, long past the point that you think you've familiarized yourself with it.
The color schemes in CA, though there are many to unlock, all seem to have a blending aspect in CA, in where getting past the 25th circle makes it impossible to see where the entry point for the current circle is. Perhaps this was intentional, but it's annoying when you sometimes can't even see your own character in a mode which is designed to be action and timing oriented (remember that CA is a separate mode from the main game).

However, all of these gripes are minor. It's a steal at $10, especially, and I'd go ahead and say to buy the soundtrack along with it (available in FLAC 48Khz/24bit for us audioheads, no less!). Due to the lack of coverage the game received, I was hesitant to buy it after discovering it, but bought it, had no regrets, and wished I could give Kenny Sun more of my money. The game deserves it. A perfectly designed experience, fantastic art style and soundtrack, and plenty of reasons to keep playing may very well make Circa Infinity a new favorite for you, as it was for me.

22785972.review:
TL;DR: I rarely like platformers and am usually too terrible to play hard games (let alone find the effort worth it when I can), and I loved Circa Infinity. Also the music is phenomenal.

Circa infinity is a certainly a hard game, but not in any conventional manner. Outside of the bosses (which you can trial and error until you get a pattern you find easier), it doesn't really require reflexes per se, or sustained timing. Hitboxes are extremely forgiving, and you can often wait between close enemies for whatever you have to do next. Enemies move predictably, and you have breathing room to plan out your next few moves, which you then execute over several quick seconds in a sigh of relief before repeating the process. It usually alternates segments like these with miniature maze-like puzzle sections you can do at whatever pace you want. Trying to play most levels like in the trailer would be extremely difficult if not impossibly the first time through. 

The game is hard because it makes you manage and respond to multiple streams of information presented on different parts of the screen. It finds new and creative ways to completely screw up your sense of direction, distance, and everything else. You'll run right into a stationary enemy you meant to run away from, or didn't see at all because you were looking at what your other character was doing. No, the game did not trick you somehow. You're just an idiot because you've never done anything like this before.

Can you pat your head and rub your stomach at the same time? How about the reverse? Change the speed of one without changing the other? Reverse directions without missing a beat? Switch between these in varying sequences? Could you learn to do all that gradually? Then you can play this. Those are the types of skills the game uses and it likes to switch things up suddenly. It's disorientingly different and every new level feels like a brick wall until you figure out the timing and order of what it wants. Then, suddenly, it seems very easy and repeatable.

Ok, an example. There's an enemy that runs continously around the circle at exactly the speed you do - enter the circle, hold down the movement key, and you're safe. They stop moving when you're in the air, so you have to be careful not to crash into the next one when you land. Then they intoduce a flying enemy that only moves when you're in the air, also at your speed. They put the in the same section of a level, so you have to jump through the air, but not too far. Then they make these enemies move in opposite directions, so you have to run in one direction, then jump in the other then switch back on landing. Then they reverse both of their directions. And then both of these completely disappear in place of enemies that move regardless of what the player is doing because there are newer and crazier gimmicks that keep getting combined in unexpected ways.

You'll move in pace with slower enemies while dodging others. You'll control two characters on opposite sides. You'll have one enter the circle before the other, so you have to avoid enemies on the inside and outside (in different places) at the same time. You'll have enemies that only appear when one character is closer. You'll run through orbs that change your characters' colors. You'll deal with enemies that can't hurt you depending on which color you are and gates that can be only opened by the right character of the right color.

It reminds me a lot of a rhythm game (or a bullet hell?) the way you're trying to process and time different patterns at the same time, and the satisfaction is similar. Considering the way the enemies animate to the beat, it's probably intentional.

My only disappointment with the game is the final boss. It's far easier, shorter, and simpler than the first one let alone all the others. I think the ending sequence was worth it, though.

18922532.review:
Circa Infinity is one of those rare games that utilizes a simple mechanic to explore a philosophical concept though subtext alone. Games like this take advantage of a potential in video games that is all-too-rarely utilized, and this alone makes it worth the download. While the last couple acts might have benefited from more development time to flesh out their original ideas, and the final boss is a bit of a letdown (WAY too easy!), the game more than makes up for it in the shear creativity of its design concepts (also note: the game's other 4 bosses are fantastic!).

This game borrows play elements from the supurb Ikaruga, and like that game it wears its Eastern influences on its sleeve. But whereas Ikaruga settled for a final boss battle with the Taijitu, the Chinese symbol that depicts the fundamantal polarity of all things in the universe, developer Kenny Sun uses this illustrated metaphor as the backdrop for his entire game. One could look at Circa Infinity as a form of mental gymnastics on the very principles of yang vs. yin, as the game forces you to process an increasing litany of opposing gameplay elements simultaneously (left vs. right, move vs. stop, jump vs. crouch, and of course, Ikaruga's color-matching black vs. white mechanics). At its core, this game is a run-and-dodge platformer in the style of the original Donkey Kong (substitute ambulating devils in the place of rolling barrels); these elements bring a fresh take to this tried-and-true genre. It all can become extremely challenging, at times even seeming to be borderline unfair. It is only when you replay earlier levels and find out how eminently do-able they are do you recognize how sound and skill-based the gameplay truly is.

In an interesting twist, Sun fuses his Eastern philosophical inspirations with Western religious iconography depicting Hell. To do this, he borrows heavily from the first act of the Divine Comedy (Dante's Inferno), complete with a tearful Satan at the center of a not-quite infinite fractal of mesmorizing concentric circles. The exit-less purgatory, with each door leading into the same room, tonally evokes Jean-Paul Sartre's famous play. The biblically unattired male and female protagonists, always just beyond an arm's reach yet doomed to chase one another for eternity, might well be Adam and Eve. In keeping with the theme of root contrast, the gender difference is depicted by the presence (or absence) of a vertically-oriented pair of cleverly placed (or omitted) pixels where the second Chakra might be. 

In utilizing spiritual symbolism from both hemispheres in a single artistic expression, one gets the sense that Kenny Sun is making a positive statement on globalism. Perhaps he is suggesting that the Devil may have a place on the Dharma Wheel alongside the metaphysically innocent. Or perhaps not! All that really matters is whether or not the game is fun, and whether you feel happy with the money and time you have invested in it when it's over. For $9.99 and 10 hours or so of gameplay (more than double if you add in the remarkably fun speedruns and challenges), I'd say it's both worth it and worthwhile. I look forward to future games from this very promising indie developer, and I hope this game garners enough support to keep him at it.

One final note: Adam and Eve are simultaneously controlled by the same commands, and in the game's third act, they also interact with the game environment and enemies in the same way. Which character becomes the subject of your default control focus vs. who you let lag behind may say something implicit about your attitude towards gender roles and how you identify with gender yourself. (It would be awesome if the game statistically tracked which character you tend to enter the circles first with!)

18077438.review:
The problem with a lot of platformers these days is that they are rarely original. Circa Infinity is not one of these platformers.

In Circa Infinity you control character(s) that are stuck in a circular world. Your objective is to reach the center ring of each level. Unlike other platformers you must use the circular world to your advantage in order to figure out how to progress to the next ring. You will encounter enemies that you will try to avoid. If you hit an enemy you will be sent back to the previous ring and will have to complete that ring again.

I would probably classify Circa Infinity as more of a puzzle platformer than just a platformer. In the later levels you really need to plan out what you are going to do or you will fail. These levels require that you approach them in a certain way or you won't be able to complete them. 

I would classify the first three worlds of the game as moderately difficult with the last two worlds being hard. Currently I am still completing levels in the last world. The challenge in Circa Infinity comes from how many things you need to keep track of at any time. In the later levels you will be keeping tracking of two characters as well as many enemies which you have to remember to avoid. At times this can be overwhelming which leads to the difficulty. 

I have had a lot of fun with Circa Infinity but I know that the game will not be for everyone. I could see the game making people with motion sickness dizzy. Also if you have trouble keeping track of a bunch of things at the same time you may have some trouble with the game.

Overall Circa Infinity is a very good puzzle platformer that succeeds in doing something new with the genre.

Note: I received a free review copy of Circa Infinity. Other than the free review copy I received no other compensation for the review.

[i]Game:[/i] Circa Infinity
[i]Genre:[/i] Abstract Platformer
[i]Developer:[/i] Kenny Sun
[i]Publisher:[/i] Kenny Sun
[i][u]Copy supplied by developer[/u][/i]

[b]Circa Infinity[/b] is an abstract platformer developed and published by Kenny Sun.

[h1]GRAPHICS[/h1]
The game feels like you are on drugs. The black and white that becomes more colorful the more you play, the circles that keep on rolling, everything makes you feel like you are on acid. While they do look good, there is nothing too spectacular to them.

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]
The game is pretty straight-forward: you must jump to enter a circle, and jump again to enter another floating circle. Then you repeat, and repeat, and repeat until you get to the final one and you beat the level. While this might sound repetitive, the more you advance into the game, the more varied the levels get: new enemies, different patterns and the constant fear of getting hit make this a gripping game that will keep you hooked for quiet some time.

[h1]CHALLENGE[/h1]
As mentioned, the game is pretty challenging, and the further you get into the game, the more it gets harder, and harder, to the point of being borderline frustrating. However, there are some safe areas in the level that are basically checkpoints in which enemies can't reach you, so you hardly ever need to restart a level from the first circle.

[h1]SOUND[/h1]
That soundtrack... Damn, if it is good. Even though it lacks in sound effects, the music is fantastic and exciting, giving a different rythm to each level and losing yourself in the acid trip that you are taking.

[h1]REPLAYABILITY[/h1]
Multiple achievements and challenges are the only thing that will make you want to complete this game. Otherwise, once you finished a level you will not want to come back to it, especially if it was though as nails.

Overall, if you enjoy platformers and games that closely resemble a drug-induced dream, this game is for you. The gameplay is easy to understand but hard to master, but it still delivers a satisfying experience.

17976950.review:
This game is a good example of what a puzzle/platform game should be.
It is not an endless runner as one might think from the captures, but a very clever frantic puzzle jumping hell.

It begins fairly easy, asking only from you some reflexes while you learn the basics, and then difficulty arise, slamming you in the face.
It is well balanced; some bits will nonetheless make you wish you dropped your controller before thinking "just one more level".
The achievements are well thought -- being what I call "usefull achievements" -- requiring from you to play the game with a different approach, making you discover how well the levels are designed (for instance, the "finish a level going only in one direction without stopping or dying", or "finish a level without moving (jumping doesn't count)").
The art style is clever and gorgeous, and the music sets you well in the mood.

Overall, it's a great game, and a gem for speedrunners!

Not sure? Try out the demo, the rest of the game is the same, WAY HARDER.

[h1]FULL VIDEO REVIEW[/h1] https://youtu.be/Je6nOhQW5sA
[h1]PROS[/h1]
[b]++Successfully balances both puzzle and platforming elements equally, resulting in a game requiring both technical skill and critical thinking[/b]
+Incredibly simplistic but extremely challenging requiring godly levels of focus
+4-6 Hours minimum if you are skilled with an additional speedrun mode that provides extra replayability
+Great soundtrack that doesn’t overstep the gameplay
[h1]CONS[/h1]
-Level of difficulty makes the game inaccessible to newer gamers or those inexperienced with the platforming genre
-Lackluster final boss

Circa Infinity is a puzzle platformer that defies expectations with its challenging, mind warping circular levels. Right as you think the game has reached its absolute hardest you are thrown a brand new mechanic that requires you to think twice as hard as you feebly attempt to focus on everything present on screen. While the game is in no doubt challenging, the pace of the game allows you to learn how to interact with its bizarre environment by gradually ramping up the difficulty by providing you consecutive stages of the same enemies but each time adding in another element. If you are into challenging platformers like Super Meat Boy or puzzle games like Portal, I highly recommend that you play Circa Infinity.

17959199.review:
Circa Infinity is a simple, but very challenging game.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PYPZ-tj5J7U
The game isn't tough due to cheap tactics, it genuinely needs fast reflexes, thinking on your feet and adapting you strategy according to certain enemies.

The goal is to find the entrance to the circle you are walking on. Once inside, you must jump into the smaller circle within to progress. Different enemies force you to act differently. Some patrol the ground and require that you jump over them, some fly and need you to walk under them. Some can go in and out of circles, and some move only when you jump.

There's also the occasional boss to fight, which is a nice break from the regular gameplay.
The game's soundtrack is actually really cool, and adds to the intense action going on.

Overall it's very cool, and I suggest you give it a shot if you're into hard games.
